intro: Alcea rosea var. tinctoria, commonly known as the common hollyhock, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is characterized by its tall, erect stems and showy, velvety flowers that come in a variety of colors. The plant belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes other plants such as cotton and hibiscus. Its leaves are ovate and have a soft, hairy texture, while its flowers are typically arranged in clusters at the ends of the stems. This variety is known for its adaptability to different soil types and its ability to thrive in full sun.
